elements.content: An ionic liquid, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide, is used as reaction medium for the synthesis and crystallization of a coordination polymer, (EMI)[Cd(BTC)] (1) (EMI = 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium, BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), which forms an anionic three-dimensional framework with 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium cations located in the void space.
elements.clean_text: An ionic liquid, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide, is used as reaction medium for the synthesis and crystallization of a coordination polymer, (EMI)[Cd(BTC)] (1) (EMI = 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium, BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), which forms an anionic three-dimensional framework with 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium cations located in the void space.

elements.content: An ionic liquid, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide, is used as a reaction medium for the synthesis and crystallization of a coordination polymer, (EMI)[Cd(BTC)] (EMI = 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium, BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), which forms an anionic three-dimensional framework with 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium cations located in the void space.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of metal−organic materials has drawn great attention because many specific properties such as ion-exchange, sorption, catalysis, and nonlinear optical properties can be achieved by molecular design. The self-assembly of multidentate organic ligands and metal ions has resulted in many coordination polymeric frameworks, whose structures are influenced by the subtle interplay of many factors such as the geometric preference of metal ions, the sizes and shapes of the organic building blocks, templates, and solvent systems.
elements.clean_text: Crystal engineering of metal-organic materials has drawn great attention because many specific properties such as ion-exchange, sorption, catalysis, and nonlinear optical properties can be achieved by molecular design. The self-assembly of multidentate organic ligands and metal ions has resulted in many coordination polymeric frameworks, whose structures are influenced by the subtle interplay of many factors such as the geometric preference of metal ions, the sizes and shapes of the organic building blocks, templates, and solvent systems.

elements.content: Lately, near-ambient temperature ionic liquids, or organic molten salts, have been extensively studied owing to their potential synthetic, electrochemical, photoelectrochemical, and phase transfer applications, which can be attributed to their characteristic physicochemical properties such as tunable solvation strength, solubility, negligible vapor pressure, high thermal stability, ionic conductivity, and heating behavior under microwave radiation. Nowadays, many pyridinium, quaternary ammonium, and dialkylimidazolium salts have been utilized as ionic liquids, which are nonflammable, nonvolatile, and are often considered as environmentally friendly solvents to replace volatile organic compounds (VOC). However, it should be noted that toxicity of ionic liquids has been reported. The application of ionic liquids in solid-state synthesis is less common; nevertheless, the number of examples of preparing nanoparicles in ionic liquids is growing. It has been reported that dialkylimidazolium cations were used as templates in aqueous solution for the synthesis of zeolites and MCM-41. Recently, a series of aluminophosphate zeolite analogues was prepared using 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide as the reaction medium and template. The first coordination polymer, [Cu(1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane)](BF4), prepared in ionic liquid, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, forms a cationic two-dimensional (2D) network with charge-compensating BF4 - anions incorporated between the layers. It is noted that a great number of coordination polymeric frameworks have been formed via the self-assembly of multidentate carboxylate linkers and metal ions. We have therefore chosen such a reaction system in an attempt to explore the feasibility of using ionic liquids as reaction media in the synthesis of coordination polymers. Here we report the application of an ionic liquid for the synthesis of the coordination polymer (EMI)[Cd(BTC)] (1), which has an anionic framework and contains 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium cations as counterions. In this experiment, the ionic liquid, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (melting point = 83 °C), was prepared under microwave radiation. The reactants (Cd(NO3)2·4H2O and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) exhibit excellent solubility in the organic molten salt, forming a clear viscous solution. The mixture was kept at 160 °C for 5 days until many chunky colorless crystals formed. The title compound was obtained in Cd-rich ratios (Cd/BTC = 3−7), while in the stoichiometric reaction (Cd/BTC = 1) no solid was obtained. The yield increases with the Cd/BTC ratio (Cd/BTC = 3, 33%; Cd/BTC = 5, 73%; Cd/BTC = 7, 83%, based on BTC). Thermogravimetric analysis indicates that 1 is stable up to ∼300 °C. The identity of the bulk product is confirmed by elemental analysis and by comparing the experimental and simulated X-ray powder diffraction patterns. The crystal structure of 1 has been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, which reveals that 1 adopts a three-dimensional (3D) framework comprising Cd2 dimeric units cross-linked by BTC ligands, as shown in Figure . Each Cd center is in a six-coordinated environment plus a Cd1···O3 contact of 2.776(4) Å, which is significantly longer than the average length of the other six Cd−O bonds (2.34 Å). The CdO6 polyhedron deviates greatly from a perfect octahedron due to the μ2-bonding mode of carboxylates. A center of inversion is located at the middle of the Cd2 moiety, which binds six BTC ligands, while each BTC is connected to three different Cd2 dimeric units. This results in the formation of an anionic MX2 framework as shown in Figure . Charge-compensating and well-defined EMI cations are observed in the void space as shown in Figure . Preliminary ion-exchange experiments by colored metal ions such as Cu2+ indicate the framework of 1 is not porous and EMI cations cannot be substituted.
elements.clean_text: Lately, near-ambient temperature ionic liquids, or organic molten salts, have been extensively studied owing to their potential synthetic, electrochemical, photoelectrochemical, and phase transfer applications, which can be attributed to their characteristic physicochemical properties such as tunable solvation strength, solubility, negligible vapor pressure, high thermal stability, ionic conductivity, and heating behavior under microwave radiation. Nowadays, many pyridinium, quaternary ammonium, and dialkylimidazolium salts have been utilized as ionic liquids, which are nonflammable, nonvolatile, and are often considered as environmentally friendly solvents to replace volatile organic compounds (VOC). However, it should be noted that toxicity of ionic liquids has been reported. The application of ionic liquids in solid-state synthesis is less common; nevertheless, the number of examples of preparing nanoparicles in ionic liquids is growing. It has been reported that dialkylimidazolium cations were used as templates in aqueous solution for the synthesis of zeolites and MCM-41. Recently, a series of aluminophosphate zeolite analogues was prepared using 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide as the reaction medium and template. The first coordination polymer, [Cu(1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane)](BF4), prepared in ionic liquid, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, forms a cationic two-dimensional (2D) network with charge-compensating BF4 - anions incorporated between the layers. It is noted that a great number of coordination polymeric frameworks have been formed via the self-assembly of multidentate carboxylate linkers and metal ions. We have therefore chosen such a reaction system in an attempt to explore the feasibility of using ionic liquids as reaction media in the synthesis of coordination polymers. Here we report the application of an ionic liquid for the synthesis of the coordination polymer (EMI)[Cd(BTC)] (1), which has an anionic framework and contains 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium cations as counterions. In this experiment, the ionic liquid, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (melting point = 83 °C), was prepared under microwave radiation. The reactants (Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) exhibit excellent solubility in the organic molten salt, forming a clear viscous solution. The mixture was kept at 160 °C for 5 days until many chunky colorless crystals formed. The title compound was obtained in Cd-rich ratios (Cd/BTC = 3-7), while in the stoichiometric reaction (Cd/BTC = 1) no solid was obtained. The yield increases with the Cd/BTC ratio (Cd/BTC = 3, 33%; Cd/BTC = 5, 73%; Cd/BTC = 7, 83%, based on BTC). Thermogravimetric analysis indicates that 1 is stable up to ~300 °C. The identity of the bulk product is confirmed by elemental analysis and by comparing the experimental and simulated X-ray powder diffraction patterns. The crystal structure of 1 has been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, which reveals that 1 adopts a three-dimensional (3D) framework comprising Cd2 dimeric units cross-linked by BTC ligands, as shown in Figure . Each Cd center is in a six-coordinated environment plus a Cd1⋅⋅⋅O3 contact of 2.776(4) Å, which is significantly longer than the average length of the other six Cd-O bonds (2.34 Å). The CdO6 polyhedron deviates greatly from a perfect octahedron due to the μ2-bonding mode of carboxylates. A center of inversion is located at the middle of the Cd2 moiety, which binds six BTC ligands, while each BTC is connected to three different Cd2 dimeric units. This results in the formation of an anionic MX2 framework as shown in Figure . Charge-compensating and well-defined EMI cations are observed in the void space as shown in Figure . Preliminary ion-exchange experiments by colored metal ions such as Cu2+ indicate the framework of 1 is not porous and EMI cations cannot be substituted.

elements.content: The ORTEP view and labeling scheme of the dimeric building block. The asymmetric unit is shown with 50% probability displacement ellipsoids. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  The ORTEP view and labeling scheme of the dimeric building block. The asymmetric unit is shown with 50% probability displacement ellipsoids. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The schematic linkage of the [Cd(BTC)]- network. Crosshatched circles represent Cd2 dimers. Small open circles represent BTC3- ligands.
elements.clean_text: 2  The schematic linkage of the [Cd(BTC)]- network. Crosshatched circles represent Cd2 dimers. Small open circles represent BTC3- ligands.

elements.content: Packing diagram of1, showing 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium cations in the void space. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Cd (green), O (red), N (blue), C (BTC:  gray; EMI:  purple).
elements.clean_text: 3  Packing diagram of1, showing 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium cations in the void space. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Cd (green), O (red), N (blue), C (BTC: gray; EMI: purple).

elements.content: In summary, this work demonstrates the application of ionic liquids, potential environmentally friendly reaction media, in the solid-state synthesis and crystallization of coordination polymers, in the temperature regime where organic species can be incorporated. The imidazolium cations are found in the void space of the coordination polymeric framework. This implies that the cations of the organic molten salts can be used as potential structure-directing templates for the crystal engineering of porous coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: In summary, this work demonstrates the application of ionic liquids, potential environmentally friendly reaction media, in the solid-state synthesis and crystallization of coordination polymers,  in the temperature regime where organic species can be incorporated. The imidazolium cations are found in the void space of the coordination polymeric framework. This implies that the cations of the organic molten salts can be used as potential structure-directing templates for the crystal engineering of porous coordination polymers.

Experimental details, XRPD patterns, IR spectrum, TGA/DSC analysis, and X-ray crystallographic files are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.asc.org.

metadata.title:
Ionic Liquid as Solvent for the Synthesis and Crystallization of a Coordination
Polymer:  (EMI)[Cd(BTC)] (EMI = 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium, BTC =
1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylate)
